entry.title: Basic Concepts of Mathematical Statistics
entry.content:
Note on Mathematical Statistics

  • A dry list of concepts as a personal review note
  • The main references is Wooldridge’s Introductory Econometrics, Appendix C (mostly). Also, wikis and googling.

Among all many concepts, probably the key ones are

  • An estimator is a random variable, thus has its sampling distribution.
  • A (test) statistic is any function of a random sample, so is a random variable itself. Defining the function is entirely up to us.

Populations, Random Variable and Random Sample

concept description comment
statistical inference learning something about a population from a sample from that population typically
  • estimation
  • hypothesis testing
population a group of all subjects (e.g. all people in the world) modelled using probability space (Ω,B,P)(\Omega, \mathcal B, P)(Ω,B,P)
random variable a numerical model for the population relationship of *interest* (e.g. height) assignment of a value (or a vector of values)
Y:Ω→RNY: \Omega \to \mathcal R^NY:Ω→RN
parameters parameters for pdf of the random variable (e.g. mean and variance) θ\thetaθ in f(y;θ)f(y; \theta)f(y;θ)
random sample a random vector (Y1,⋯ ,Yn)(Y_1, \cdots, Y_n)(Y1​,⋯,Yn​), consisting of independent random variables (not realisations) with the common pdf f(y;θ)f(y;\theta)f(y;θ) of YYY YiY_iYi​ are known to be independent, identically distributed (i.i.d.)

Estimator and Estimate

Setup: Random Sampling

From a given random variable, construct a random sample

notation description
YYY a random variable representing a poulation with pdf f(y;θ)f(y;\theta)f(y;θ)
Y1,⋯ ,YnY_1, \cdots, Y_nY1​,⋯,Yn​ a random vector of YYY
μ\muμ the mean of YYY
σ2\sigma^2σ2 the variance of YYY

Examples of Estimators

Some of the most commonly referenced estimators are

estimator definition comments
sample average Yˉ=n−1∑i=1nYi\bar{Y} = n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n} Y_iYˉ=n−1∑i=1n​Yi​
  • unbiased estimator for μ\muμ.
  • no assumption is required
sample variance with unknown μ\muμ S2=1n−1∑i=1n(Yi−Yˉ)2S^2 = \frac{1}{n-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n} (Y_i - \bar Y)^2S2=n−11​i=1∑n​(Yi​−Yˉ)2
  • unbiased estimator for σ2\sigma^2σ2.
  • If 1/n−11/n-11/n−1 is replaced by 1/n1/n1/n, it is consistent but not unbiased.
sample variance with known μ\muμ S2=1n∑i=1n(Yi−μ)2S^2 = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} (Y_i - \mu)^2S2=n1​i=1∑n​(Yi​−μ)2 unbiased estimator for σ2\sigma^2σ2.
sample standard deviation S=S2S = \sqrt{S^2}S=S2​
  • not an unbiased estimator of σ\sigmaσ.
  • a consistent estimator of σ\sigmaσ
standard error of the mean se=Sn\mathrm{se} = \frac{S}{\sqrt{n}}se=n​S​
  • An estimator of the standard deviation of the sampling distribution of Yˉ\bar{Y}Yˉ.
  • Generally, the standard error of any statistic (usually parameter estimator) can be described (wiki)

Concepts

Tabularizing some of the key concepts:

concept description comments
estimator of θ\thetaθ a function of a random sample as a rule to assign
each outcome of the sample →\to→ a value of θ\thetaθ
W=h(Y1,⋯ ,Yn)W = h(Y_1, \cdots, Y_n)W=h(Y1​,⋯,Yn​)
  • Being a *random variable*, the standard convention is to use a capital letter (e.g. Yˉ\bar {Y}Yˉ for μ\muμ)
  • The practical convention, however, is to denote it by θ^\hat{\theta}θ^, which is the same practical convention for the estimate (e.g. μ^\hat{\mu}μ^​)
estimate The specific value of hhh with a particular outcome
w=h(y1,⋯ ,yn)w = h(y_1, \cdots, y_n)w=h(y1​,⋯,yn​)
  • Being a value (not a random variable), the standard convention is to use the lower case of the estimator (e.g. yˉ\bar{y}yˉ​)
  • The practical convention is, however, to denote it by θ^\hat{\theta}θ^, which is the same practical convention for the estimator (e.g. μ^\hat{\mu}μ^​)
sampling distribution The distribution of an estimator
  • In short, the statistical inference is to study the sampling distribution.
sampling variance the variance of an estimator, and thus a constant and not a random variable. This should not be confused with the sample variance, which is an estimator (so a random variable) of σ2\sigma^2σ2. For example, the sampling variance of the sample average is given by (easy to show) Var(Yˉ)=σ2/n.\mathrm{Var}(\bar{Y}) = \sigma^2/n.Var(Yˉ)=σ2/n.
unbiased Estimator An estimate WWW of θ\thetaθ is *unbiased* if E(W)=θE(W) = \thetaE(W)=θ for all possible values of θ\thetaθ
  • Notably, Yˉ\bar{Y}Yˉ and S2S^2S2 are unbiased estimators for μ\muμ and σ2\sigma^2σ2, respectively.
  • Unbiasedness does not imply that the estimate is equal to θ\thetaθ.
  • Unbiased estimator can be quite poor (e.g. μ^=Y1)\hat{\mu} = Y_1)μ^​=Y1​).
Bias of Estimator Defined as Bias(W):=E(W)−θ.\mathrm{Bias}(W) := E(W) - \theta.Bias(W):=E(W)−θ.
Efficiency Let W1W_1W1​ and W2W_2W2​ be two unbiased estimators of θ\thetaθ. W1W_1W1​ is efficient relative to W2W_2W2​ if
Var(W1)≤Var(W2)\mathrm{Var}(W_1) \le \mathrm{Var}(W_2)Var(W1​)≤Var(W2​)
for all θ\thetaθ, with strict inequality for at least one value of θ\thetaθ
  • Yˉ\bar{Y}Yˉ is the most efficient (has the smallest variance) among all unbiased estimators that are linear combinations of the random sample (not difficult to show)
  • In general, it is possible to have two unbiased estimationrs where one has smaller variances for some values of θ\thetaθ while the other has smaller variance for other values of θ\thetaθ.
mean squared error (MSE) MSE(W)=E[(W−θ)2]\mathrm{MSE}(W) = E[(W-\theta)^2]MSE(W)=E[(W−θ)2]
Unlike efficieny, MSE can be used whether the estimators are unbiased or biased. 		can show
MSE(W)=Var(W)+[Bias(W)]2\mathrm{MSE}(W) = \mathrm{Var}(W) + [\mathrm{Bias}(W)]^2MSE(W)=Var(W)+[Bias(W)]2
consistency Let WnW_nWn​ be an estimator of θ\thetaθ based on a random sample of size nnn. WnW_nWn​ is a consistent estimator of θ\thetaθ if Wn→θW_n \to \thetaWn​→θ.
  • More precisely, for every ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0,
    P(∣Wn−θ∣>ϵ)→0 as n→∞P(|W_n-\theta| > \epsilon) \to 0 \ \textrm{as}\ n \to \inftyP(∣Wn​−θ∣>ϵ)→0 as n→∞
  • Here, θ\thetaθ is said to be the probability limit of WnW_nWn​, denoted as
    plim⁡(Wn)=θ\plim(W_n)=\thetaplim(Wn​)=θ

Law of Large Numbers and Central Limit Theorem: Classical results on sample average

concept description comments
law of large numbers (LLN) Let Yˉn\bar{Y}_nYˉn​ be the same average of Y1,⋯ ,YnY_1, \cdots, Y_nY1​,⋯,Yn​. Then, plim⁡n→∞Ynˉ=μ\plim_{n\to\infty} \bar{Y_n} = \mun→∞plim​Yn​ˉ​=μ
  • Thus, the sample average is a consistent estimator.
  • This is the weak law of large numbers [wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_of_large_numbers). If σ2\sigma^2σ2 is assumed to be finite, this law is not only easy to prove but we have a more precise statement, the central limit theorem.
  • For the strong law and related proof, see Prof Tao's blog.
central limit theorem Let ZnZ_nZn​ be the standardised version of Yˉn\bar{Y}_nYˉn​ Zn=Yˉn−μσ/nZ_n = \frac{\bar{Y}_n - \mu}{\sigma/n}Zn​=σ/nYˉn​−μ​ Then, it converges in distribution to the standard normal: P(Zn≤z)→Φ(z) as n→∞P(Z_n \le z) \to \Phi(z) \ \textrm{as}\ n \to \inftyP(Zn​≤z)→Φ(z) as n→∞
  • σ2\sigma^2σ2 is assumed to be finite (otherwise, ZnZ_nZn​ would not be defined).
  • Whilst the law of large numbers says the sample average converges to μ\muμ, this class central limit theorem describes the distributional aspect around μ\muμ.
  • This is the classical central limit theorem.
  • One can replace σ\sigmaσ by SnS_nSn​ (sample standard deviation).

Confidence Interval Estimator

concept description comments
confidence interval estimator Given a confidence level γ\gammaγ (e.g. 95%), a confidence interval estimator for θ\thetaθ is an interval such that P(u(Y1,⋯ ,Yn)<θ<v(Y1,⋯ ,Yn))=γP(u(Y_1, \cdots, Y_n) < \theta < v(Y_1, \cdots, Y_n)) = \gammaP(u(Y1​,⋯,Yn​)<θ<v(Y1​,⋯,Yn​))=γ
  • The boundary values u(Y1,⋯ ,Yn)u(Y_1, \cdots, Y_n)u(Y1​,⋯,Yn​) and v(Y1,⋯ ,Yn)v(Y_1, \cdots, Y_n)v(Y1​,⋯,Yn​) are random variables.
  • Interval estimate is the interval when a specific realisations of YiY_iYi​ are plugged into uuu and vvv.

Application to the mean of a normal
Recall that, if YYY is normal, the standardised version of (the sampling distribution of) the sample average follows a ttt-distribution:

The most common interval estimator with the confidence level γ:=(1−α)\gamma := (1-\alpha)γ:=(1−α) is

where cα/2c_{\alpha/2}cα/2​ is the 100(1−α/2)100(1-\alpha/2)100(1−α/2)-th percentile in the tn−1t_{n-1}tn−1​ sitribution.

Hypothesis Testing and Test Statistic

A hypothesis test is about rejecting or not rejecting a null hypothesis.

concept description comments
null hypothesis The statement being tested.
A typical form is H0:θ=θ0H_0:\theta = \theta_0H0​:θ=θ0​ where θ\thetaθ is the true parameter (or the collection of true parameters or the model itself) based on the population.
  • The null hypothesis is presumed to be true until the data strongly suggest otherwise. Just as a defendent is presumed to be innocent util proven guilty.
  • For example, the hypothetical testing on a null hypothesis H0:μ=0H_0: \mu = 0H0​:μ=0 is not about proving the mean is (this would be a very difficult task if the true value were 0.000001).
alternative hypothesis The statement being tested against the null hypothesis.
A typical form is either one-sided H1:θ<θ0 or H1:θ>θ0H_1: \theta < \theta_0 \ \textrm{or} \ H_1: \theta > \theta_0H1​:θ<θ0​ or H1​:θ>θ0​ or two-sided: H1:θ not equal θ0H_1: \theta \text{ not equal } \theta_0H1​:θ not equal θ0​.
  • To conclude that H0H_0H0​ is false and H1H_1H1​ is true, there should be evidence "beyond reasonable doubt" against H0H_0H0​, which is quantified with respect to the significance level (e.g. 5%).
  • The one-sided alternative hypothesis, say θ<θ0\theta < \theta_0θ<θ0​, is used when it is not of an interest to show the other side of relation θ>θ0\theta > \theta_0θ>θ0​. Showing a defendent is more than innocent is not of the interest in proving guilty.
Type I error & significant level
  • Type I error: Rejecting the null hypothesis when it is in fact true
  • significant level α\alphaα of a test: the probability of a Type 1 error α=P(Type I)=P(Reject H0∣H0)\alpha = P(\text{Type I}) = P(\text{Reject }H_0|H_0)α=P(Type I)=P(Reject H0​∣H0​) or, equivalently α=P(Reject H0;θ=θ0)\alpha = P(\text{Reject }H_0 ; \theta={\color{blue} \theta_0})α=P(Reject H0​;θ=θ0​)
  • Type I error is also known as false negative, which means that H0H_0H0​ is falsely deemed to be positive (rejected).
  • The significant level is set before the test. Common values are 10%, 5% and 1% although there are no clear justifications for them.
  • By the way, why am I using ';' instead of '|'? See here
Type II error & power
  • Type II error: Failing to reject the null hypothesis when it is in fact false.
  • power of a test π(θ1)\pi({\color{red} \theta_1})π(θ1​) against a relevant and specific alternative θ=θ1\theta = {\color{red} \theta_1}θ=θ1​: π(θ1)=P(Reject H0;θ=θ1)\pi({\color{red} \theta_1}) = P(\text{Reject }H_0 ; \theta={\color{red} \theta_1})π(θ1​)=P(Reject H0​;θ=θ1​) or, equivalently π(θ1)=1−P(Type II;θ=θ1)\pi({\color{red} \theta_1}) = 1 - P(\text{Type II} ; \theta={\color{red} \theta_1})π(θ1​)=1−P(Type II;θ=θ1​)
  • type II error is also known as false positive, which means that H0H_0H0​ is falsely deemed to be positive (not rejected).
  • Notice that a test's power is against a specific alternative hypothesis, making it as a function π(θ1)\pi({\color{red} \theta_1})π(θ1​) of θ1{\color{red} \theta_1}θ1​.
  • Whilst a power is loosely referred as P(Reject H0;H1 is true)P(\text{Reject }H_0 ; H_1 \text{ is true})P(Reject H0​;H1​ is true), it is difficult to calculate as H1H_1H1​ is typically not an equality.
  • For a binary classification, there is only one alternativate and the power is called sensitivity.
  • Factors that make a power larger: significant level, difference in θ0\theta_0θ0​ and θ1\theta_1θ1​, sample size
  • In practice, a power is denoted simply as π(θ)=P(Reject H1∣θ)\pi(\theta) = P(\text{Reject }H_1|\theta)π(θ)=P(Reject H1​∣θ).

An examples in wiki is illustrating where the hypotheses are H0:μ=0H_0:\mu=0H0​:μ=0 and H1:μ=1H_1:\mu=1H1​:μ=1. The power for μ=θ\mu = \thetaμ=θ is given by

where the central limit theorm is applied for approximation. Observe that the power increases if

  • a larger confidence level α\alphaα (though ccc) is taken,
  • θ\thetaθ is taken further from 000, or
  • nnn increases.

Back to describing concepts:

concept description comments
test statistic a function of a random sample used in (statistical) hypothesis testing
Denoted by TTT below.
  • Recall that a statistic is any function of a random sample; it is called an estimator if used for estimating a parameters while called a test statistic if used for hypothesis testing.
  • Almost always, a test statistic takes values in R\mathcal RR.
  • For a list of test statistics, see wiki.
rejection region & critical value
  • If ttt (a realisation of TTT) is inside the rejection region RcR_cRc​, H0H_0H0​ is rejected in favor of H1H_1H1​.
  • The boundary of the rejection region are called a critical value ccc.
  • We have P(T∈Rc;H0)=αP(T \in R_c ; H_0) = \alphaP(T∈Rc​;H0​)=α
  • If TTT is real-valued,
    • one-sided left-tail: Rc={t<c} and P(T<c)=αR_c = \{ t < c \} \text{ and } P(T < c) = \alphaRc​={t<c} and P(T<c)=α
    • one-sided right-tail: Rc={t>c} and P(T>c)=αR_c = \{ t > c\} \text { and } P(T > c) = \alphaRc​={t>c} and P(T>c)=α
    • two-sided: Rc={t<c1 or t>c1}R_c = \{ t < c_1 \text{ or } t > c_1 \}Rc​={t<c1​ or t>c1​} and P(T<c1)=P(T>c1)=α/2P(T < c_1) = P(T > c_1) = \alpha/2P(T<c1​)=P(T>c1​)=α/2
p-value Consider a random sample Y1,⋯ ,YnY_1, \cdots, Y_nY1​,⋯,Yn​, and fix a test-statistic TTT for a hypothesis testing.
  • The p-value is the largest significance level at which we fail to reject the null hypothesis.
  • For a given realisation ttt, the probability to observe at least as extreme as ttt if H0H_0H0​ is assumed to be true. Thus,
    • one-sided left-tail: p=P(T<t;H0)p = P(T < t; H_0)p=P(T<t;H0​)
    • one-sided right-tail: p=P(T>t;H0)p = P(T > t; H_0)p=P(T>t;H0​)
    • two-sided and symmetric TTT: p=P(∣T∣>∣t∣;H0)p = P(|T|>|t|; H_0)p=P(∣T∣>∣t∣;H0​)
    For two-sided with asymmetric TTT, there seems to be debates.
  • p-value is a random variable.
  • Debates on the p-value for a two-tail test with asymmetric TTT: here.
    • consistent with the definition with symmetric rejection regions: p=2min⁡{P(T<t;H0),P(T>t;H0)}p = 2 \min\{ P(T < t; H_0), P(T > t; H_0) \}p=2min{P(T<t;H0​),P(T>t;H0​)} (proof: not reject if P(T<t)≥α/2)P(T < t ) \ge \alpha/2)P(T<t)≥α/2) and P(T>t)≤1−α/2P(T > t) \le 1-\alpha/2P(T>t)≤1−α/2. The largest of such α\alphaα is ppp.)
    • use the likelihood function p=P(f(T)<f(t))p = P(f(T) < f(t))p=P(f(T)<f(t)) (this is like a one-sided test with the test-statistic f(T)f(T)f(T))
    In the end, the p-value depends on the choice of the test-statistic TTT. It is up to us which one is better one.

Application to multinomial distribution

Definition:

  • Non-standard definition: A multinomial random vector with KKK categories with NNN trial is a vector-valued test-statistic (X1,⋯ ,XK)(X_1, \cdots, X_K)(X1​,⋯,XK​) from a random sample Y1,⋯ ,YNY_1, \cdots, Y_NY1​,⋯,YN​ of a categorical random variable YYY where
    • YnY_nYn​ takes a value in {1,⋯ ,K}{1, \cdots, K}{1,⋯,K} with an event probability pkp_kpk​ satisfying ∑k=1Kpk=1\sum_{k=1}^{K} p_k = 1∑k=1K​pk​=1.
    • XkX_kXk​ is the count of YnY_nYn​ such that Yn=kY_n = kYn​=k.
      By definition, ∑k=1KXk=n\sum_{k=1}^{K} X_k = n∑k=1K​Xk​=n.
  • Standard versions are in wiki and here

Unlike the examples we have seen so far, the random sampling is already embedded within the multinomial distribution. Thus, for a given realisation (x1,⋯ ,xK)(x_1, \cdots, x_K)(x1​,⋯,xK​) with ∑k=1Kxk=n\sum_{k=1}^{K}x_k = n∑k=1K​xk​=n, one can form a hypothesis testing whether it is from a multinomial distribution with event probabilities pkp_kpk​.

See here for several test-statistics used to this end.

entry.title: Bayesian Inference
entry.content:
source source

This post is a personal review on the Bayesian Inference.

Prior and Posterial Probabilities

pictorial illustration

A tree diagram would be the simplest way to illustrate the approach.

The left and right sides show prior and posterial probabilities, respectively. Given the prior probabilities P(A)P(A)P(A) and P(B)P(B)P(B) (which is 1−P(A)1-P(A)1−P(A) by definition), the posterial probabilities P(A∣C)P(A|C)P(A∣C), P(B∣C)P(B|C)P(B∣C), P(A∣D)P(A|D)P(A∣D) and P(B∣D)P(B|D)P(B∣D) are the updated probabilities after taking into account the events CCC and DDD (which is the complement of CCC).

formal derivation

The formal derivation is simple

Examples

Covid (or any medical) test

Notation:

  • YYY and NNN are the events of being infected or not infected from Covid, respectively.
  • +++ and −-− indicates the test results, positive and negative, respectively.

Prior probabilities: The test kit should disclose

  • sensitivity (true positive rate): P(+∣Y)P(+|Y)P(+∣Y)
  • specificity (true negative rate): P(−∣N)P(-|N)P(−∣N)

Table with all prior probabilities:

test \ covid Y N
+ P(+∣Y)P( + \vert Y) P(+∣Y): sensitivity, true positive P(+∣N)P(+\vert N)P(+∣N): false positive
- P(−∣Y)P(-\vert Y) P(−∣Y): false negative P(−∣N)P(-\vert N)P(−∣N): specificity, true negative
sum 1 1

Posterior probabilities: When we perform a test, we would like to know

  • P(Y∣+)P(Y|+)P(Y∣+): correct test result
  • P(Y∣−)P(Y|-)P(Y∣−): incorrect test result

Table with all posterial probabilities:

test \ covid Y N sum
+ P(Y∣+)P(Y \vert +)P(Y∣+): correct P(N∣+)P(N \vert +)P(N∣+): incorrect 1
- P(Y∣−)P(Y \vert -)P(Y∣−): incorrect P(N∣−)P(N \vert -)P(N∣−): correct 1

Now, let’s consider the RLF test kit, which has 99.9% sensitivity, or
P(+∣Y)=P(−∣N)=0.999P(+|Y) = P(-|N) = 0.999P(+∣Y)=P(−∣N)=0.999
Then, we have
P(Y∣+)=P(+∣Y)P(Y)P(+∣Y)P(Y)+P(+∣N)P(N)P(Y|+) = \frac{P(+|Y)P(Y)}{P(+|Y)P(Y) + P(+|N)P(N)}P(Y∣+)=P(+∣Y)P(Y)+P(+∣N)P(N)P(+∣Y)P(Y)​
and
P(Y∣−)=P(−∣Y)P(Y)P(−∣Y)P(Y)+P(−∣N)P(N)P(Y|-) = \frac{P(-|Y)P(Y)}{P(-|Y)P(Y) + P(-|N)P(N)}P(Y∣−)=P(−∣Y)P(Y)+P(−∣N)P(N)P(−∣Y)P(Y)​

The prior infection probability P(Y)=1−P(N)P(Y) = 1-P(N)P(Y)=1−P(N) is varied between 0 and 0.001 (0.1%), and an alternative sensitivity assumption 0.990.990.99 (rubbish kit) is also considered:

Suppose that the prevailing infection probabilty is at 1/1000. If the test kit shows a positive result, I have about 50% chance to have a Covid. In comparison, a positive result from a rubbish kit means about 10% chance. In both cases, if negative test result means that there is almost no chance to have a Covid (so, you can go out).

entry.title: Treasury Bond Yield Curve
entry.content:
FT reports “US 10-year Treasury yield reaches 3% for first time since 2018” in 2nd May 2022. But, what do they mean by US 10-year Treasury? Nowhere in the article, they defined what it was and mostly likely it was the yield rate of the most recently-issued (also known as on-the-run) 10-year note (see here for various debt types inclduing note), or possibly the yield implied from the futures contract on 10-year tenor (see here). But, what about 30-year bond issued 20 years ago (referred to as vintaged) with 10-year time-to-maturity left? How is it related to the headline 10-year yield?

All Bonds

Most market data sites such as yahoo show the yields at only a few benchmark tenors such as 2-, 5-, 10- and 30-years. But, there are many more bonds out there. Limiting ourselfs to only conventional bonds (fixed-coupon bonds of type ‘note’ and ‘bond’), the figure below shows a scatter plot of time-to-maturity and yield pairs across all relevant ISINs as of 15th June 2022 (a historic date when the Federal Reserve increase the fund rate by 75bp).

  • price data sourced from TreasuryDirect
  • yields (dots) are calculated using Python QuantLib Bond library.
  • The backbone curve (dashed line) is calculated by applying a rolling average.

While the yield data provides a reasonably smooth term-structure, there are some notable deviations from the backbone curve, e.g. near 20y tenor. In the rest of this article, we look at the basis quantities (differences between the ISIN-specific yield rates and the backbone rates) to learn underlying structures.

On-the-run and Vintaged

First, the plot below shows that the yields from the 20y bonds (brown line) are significantly different from those from the 10y-old 30y bonds (pinks). One reasonable explanation is the difference in coupon size as indicated by the marker size. The 30y bonds issued 10 years ago had larger coupons than those issued recently.

Next, we focus on 5y (green), 7y (red) and 10y (purple) bonds. For each of the branches, the far-right point corresponds to the most recently-issued security, known as on-the-run. In general(not always), the demand on such bonds is high and leads to higher valuations (equivalently, lower their yields). This is indeed the case for the yields for the 5y- and 10y- on-the-run bonds. However, it is certainly not the case for the 7-year on-the-run bond, which has a higher yield than other 7-year bonds.

Finally, we focus on 2y (blue) and 3y (orange) bonds below and make similar observations as above.

entry.title: Catalan Triangle - an alternative proof
entry.content:
Random Walk and Back to Origin

Consider a random walk with 50/50 chance to go up/down by a unit. Let XnX_nXn​ be the location after nnn-th step with X0=0X_0 = 0X0​=0. How many ways are there to come back to the original location at the 2n2n2n-th step with

in other words, while staying positive? The answer to this question is known to be the (n−1)\color{red} (n-1)(n−1)-the Catalan number.

The nnn-th Catalan number C(n)C(n)C(n) is defined as

Whilst there are many ways to prove this, I would like to present my way as an alternative.

Pascal’s Triangle

Let’s consider Pascal’s triangle where the kkk-th element of the nnn-th row is given by

where n=0,1,⋯ ,n = 0, 1, \cdots, n=0,1,⋯, and k=0,1,⋯ ,nk = 0, 1, \cdots, nk=0,1,⋯,n.

The triangle can be depicted as below

where n=0n = 0n=0 corresponds to the top row and k=0k=0k=0 corresponds to the far left circle in each row.

The triangle is thought to be constructed by

  1. fill the space with zeros: P(n,k)=0P(n,k) = 0P(n,k)=0 for nnn and kkk all integers (negative integers as well)
  2. drop one at the yellow circle: P(0,0)=1P(0,0) = 1P(0,0)=1
  3. let it cascade down through
  4. update n←n+1n \leftarrow n+1n←n+1 and go back to step 3.

The triangle tracks the number of possible paths to each circle from the starting yellow circle with

left half center line right half
Xn>0\color{blue} X_n > 0Xn​>0 Xn=0X_n=0Xn​=0 Xn<0\color{red} X_n < 0Xn​<0

Hence, in the absence of condition (), the answer is just to read off the values along the center line: 2, 6, 20, 70, etc, or

Catalan’s Triangle

The condition () can be incorporated by adding the step between step 3 and 4:
(step 3.5): If nnn is even, overwrite the value (red circles below) at the center to zero

The same result can be achieved if we reverse the sign of the values in the right half and perform the standard Pascal triangle operation without overwriting.

This triangle is the sum of the two Pascal’s triangles starting from the yellow circles above, respectively.

triangle 1 triangle 2
constructed by dropping +1 at (1,0) at step 2 dropping -1 at (1,1) at step 2
value P1(n,k)=(n−1k)P_1(n,k) = \left( \begin{array}{c} n-1 \ k \end{array} \right) P1​(n,k)=(n−1k​) P2(n,k)=−(n−1k−1)P_2(n,k) = -\left( \begin{array}{c} n-1 \ k-1 \end{array} \right)P2​(n,k)=−(n−1k−1​)

Then, the number of possible paths to return to zero at 2n2n2n is the value at (2n-1, n-1) as highlighted in grey, i.e. 1, 1, 2, 5, 14, …

entry.title: Debug Jupyter Python Notebook via VS Code
entry.content:
VS Code finally supports debugging for its own Jupyter Notebook. See ‘October 2021 Release’, and it works like a charm.

The following is still useful with the standard version of Jupyter Notebook (e.g. through web browsers).

Background

When writing a notebook using Jupyter (Notebook or Lab), it is common to write actual codes as separate modules (.py) and call them from the notebook. In this post, we show how to use VS Code debugger from Jupyter to debug (i) cells within Jupyter and (ii) codes in .py files. Surprisingly, I couldn’t find any memos explaining this elsewhere.

Preparation

  • Install debugpy
  • Add a new config in VS Code

    • click the bug/triangle button on the left.

    • click the gear button. This will open launch.json

    • click Add Configuration -> Python -> Remote Attach

    • simply accept the defaults (host = localhost, port = 5678) by pressing enters twice.

    • This will create an additional config

Action

  • Here is an example:
VS Code Jupyter
  • From Jupyter: Execute step 3.
  • Go back to VS Code and Select Python: Remote Attach and click the green triange
  • Then, you will be connected and should be able to see the following:
  • From Jupyter, exceute step 4. The breakpoint() command invokes a debug activity.
  • Then, go back to VS Code. The cell is copied into a temperary file in VS Code. You can debug the codes in the usual way.

not found?

If the debugger does not find the relevant file, it is most likely that the path mapping needs to be specified.

entry.title: Using FFTW and pyFFTW
entry.content:
FFTW is a popular C-library for computing the discrete Fourier transform and its documentation page provides comprehesive information on the library. For Python, pyFFTW provides an excellent wrapper. Below, we show a simple example in both C and Python versions to illustrate how the Python wrapper corresponds to the actual library.

Xk=∑k=0N−1e−2πik/NxiX_{k} = \sum_{k=0}^{N-1} e^{-2\pi i k / N} x_iXk​=k=0∑N−1​e−2πik/Nxi​

Example

The example does the follow calls:

  • allocate spaces for x, y, and z (z_N in C version), each of which has N complex numbers.
  • set up fft and ifft plans.
    • fft: from x to y
    • ifft: from y to z (z_N in C version)
  • fill x with cos(3 * pi * t) and call fft to get y.
  • fill x with cos(5 * pi * t) and call fft to get a different y.
  • call ifft on y to get z (z_N in C version)
  • compared to x.
    • In C, z_N is the same to x * N because the library does not include the scale factor.
    • In Python, z is the same to x because the wrapper adds the scale factor.

Both versions together

To see both versions together, click the image below. The left panel is in C and the right panel is in Python. Extra spaces are added to the Python version so that the two versions are aligned line-by-line.

Codes: C

Codes: Python

entry.title: Illustration of Volatility Clustering using Garch
entry.content:
Source Codes:

  • Jupyter notebook
  • folder

Opening

In financial time series data, it is common to observe volatility clusturing, meanining large changes tend to be clustered. For example, the figure below shows daily returns (light blues) of the S&P500 index where one can observe clusters of larges changes during 2009 (financial crisis) and 2020 (Covid-19 stress).

In this document, we demonstrate how the volatility clustering phenomena can be analysed using Garch(1,1), one of the model simplest models featuring heteroskedasticity (a fancy word indicating that the volatility is varying over time as indicated by the red line in the above figure.)

Garch(1,1) Model

The model describes the dynamics for return variable rtr_trt​ and volatility variable σt\sigma_tσt​:
\begin{eqnarray}
r_t&=&\mu+\sigma_t\epsilon_t \label{E:garch-return}\
\sigma_{t+1}^2 & = &\sigma_\infty^2(1 - \beta-\gamma) + \beta \sigma_{t}^2 + \gamma \sigma_{t}2\epsilon_{t}2 \label{E:garch-vol}\
\end{eqnarray}
where

  • ϵt\epsilon_tϵt​ is the innovation variable, assumed to be Gaussian (for simplicity) and i.i.d. over time.
  • μ\muμ is the drift parameter for rtr_trt​
  • σ∞\sigma_\inftyσ∞​, β\betaβ and γ\gammaγ are Garch(1,1) model parameters with
    σ∞>0,β≥0,γ≥0,β+γ<1.\sigma_\infty > 0,\quad \beta \ge 0, \quad \gamma \ge 0,\quad \beta + \gamma < 1.σ∞​>0,β≥0,γ≥0,β+γ<1.

References: See this wiki page for the model general model Garch(p,q) as well as other Garch families.

Properties

The followings are some of notable properties of the model:

  • Re-writing the second equation above, it is easy to see that the Garch volatility σt\sigma_tσt​ is mean-reverting:
    \begin{equation}
    \sigma_{t+1}^2 - \sigma_{t}^2 = (1 -\beta - \gamma)(\sigma_{\infty}^2 - \sigma_{t}^2) + \gamma\sigma_{t}2(\epsilon_{t}2-1)
    \end{equation}
    where σt\sigma_tσt​ is the mean-reverting level and (1−β−γ)(1-\beta-\gamma)(1−β−γ) is the mean-reverting speed.
  • Given the information up to today ttt, the expected forward variance at τ>t\tau > tτ>t is fully determined and calculated as
    \begin{eqnarray*}
    \bar{\sigma}^2_t(\tau) & := & E[\sigma_{t+\tau}^2| \mathcal F_t ]\
    & = & \sigma_{\infty}^2 + (\beta+\gamma){\tau-1}(\sigma_{t+1}2 - \sigma_\infty^2)
    \end{eqnarray*}
  • Then, the expected spot variance over tenor τ\tauτ is given by

Garch Filtering

Denoting the index price time series as
S0,S1,⋯ ,St,⋯ ,S_0, S_1, \cdots, S_t, \cdots,S0​,S1​,⋯,St​,⋯,
the goal is to derive the Garch volatility time series (red line in the above figure)
σ0,σ1,⋯ ,σt,⋯ .\sigma_0, \sigma_1, \cdots, \sigma_t, \cdots.σ0​,σ1​,⋯,σt​,⋯.

To this end,

  • Set rtr_trt​ is the log-change of StS_{t}St​, i.e.
    rt=ln⁡St/St−1.r_t = \ln { S_t / S_{t-1}}.rt​=lnSt​/St−1​.
  • μ\muμ and σ∞\sigma_\inftyσ∞​ are set to the unconditional mean and standard deviation of {rt}{r_t}{rt​} over all available data, respectively.
  • For now, we set β=0.9\beta = 0.9β=0.9 and γ=0.09\gamma = 0.09γ=0.09, which would be within typical ranges (based on google search). The estimation method is discussed later this document.

Then, σt\sigma_tσt​ can be derived using the following simple recursive algorithm:

  • Initialise: σ02=σ∞2\sigma^2_0 = \sigma^2_\inftyσ02​=σ∞2​ (or other value that is defendable)
  • Assume that we have the volatility σt\sigma_tσt​ as of time ttt. Then,
    1. Set the innovation term ϵt=(rt−μ)/σt\epsilon_t = (r_t - \mu) / \sigma_tϵt​=(rt​−μ)/σt​, which is from ().
    2. Set the next volatility σt+1\sigma_{t+1}σt+1​ using ().

The above algorithm produces the corresponding innovation time series (illustrated figure below)
ϵ1,⋯ ,ϵt,⋯ ,\epsilon_1, \cdots, \epsilon_t, \cdots,ϵ1​,⋯,ϵt​,⋯,
which are daily returns with Garch volatilities removed.

While one may run many statistical tests, it is visually obvious that the filtered returns (ϵt\epsilon_tϵt​) are more i.i.d. than the original returns (rtr_trt​). So, from the statistically perspective, the former samples are more meaningful to work with.

Simulation

To simulate a sample path using Garch(1,1), we generate samples for the innovation variable ϵt\epsilon_tϵt​. For illustration purposes, the standard normal random variable is used although other variables such as Student-t distributions can be used as well. The top/left figure below shows simulated returns (in light blue) using Garch(1,1) together with the corresponding Garch volatilities (in red). Volatility clustering pheonomena are clearly visible. To contrast, the bottom/left figure shows simulated returns when the geometric brownian motion (GBM) is applied (by setting β=γ=0\beta=\gamma=0β=γ=0) with constant volatility σ∞\sigma_\inftyσ∞​.

returns levels

Finally, for simulated price paths, set an initial value, say 0, and sum the returns cumulatively, and take the exponential to obtain the paths in the right figure above.

Estimation: MLE

So far, we have postulated certain values for β\betaβ and γ\gammaγ without justifications. In this section, we estimate them by applying the standard maximum likelihood estimation method.

Objective Function

To this end, noting that σt\sigma_tσt​ is determined one time step in advance:
rt∣Ft−1∼N(μ,σt2),r_t | \mathcal F_{t-1} \sim \mathcal N (\mu, \sigma_{t}^2),rt​∣Ft−1​∼N(μ,σt2​),
the likelihood function for time step ttt is given as
\begin{equation}
l(r_t|\mathcal F_{t-1}) = \displaystyle \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi \sigma_t^2}}
\exp\left( - \frac{(r_t - \mu)2}{2\sigma_t2}\right).
\end{equation}
Thus, we can write the objective function to maximize as below after doing the usual steps (multiply over samples, take log to turn into sum, ignore constant factors)
\begin{equation}
L(\beta, \gamma) = -\sum_{t} \left[ \ln \sigma_t^2 + \frac{(r_t - \mu)2}{\sigma_t2}\right].
\end{equation}

Optimisation

Before running the actual optimisation function, we calculate LLL over a range of β\betaβ and γ\gammaγ values with constraint β+γ<1\beta + \gamma < 1β+γ<1 and obtain the following contour plot which indicates where the maximum is roughly located.

Running an optimisation routine (e.g. Nelder-Mead), the maximum is achieved at
(β,γ)=(0.88035162,0.10633708),(\beta, \gamma) = (0.88035162, 0.10633708),(β,γ)=(0.88035162,0.10633708),
which is not too far from our postulated values (0.9, 0.09).

In Closing

When β+γ=1\beta+\gamma=1β+γ=1, we have
σt+12=βσt2+(1−β)(rt−μ)2\sigma_{t+1}^2 = \beta \sigma_{t}^2 + (1-\beta) \left( r_t - \mu \right)^2σt+12​=βσt2​+(1−β)(rt​−μ)2
which can be easily shown to be the EWMA volatility. For typical parametrisations (e.g. \beta = 0.9), EWMA volatilities are very close to Garch(1,1) volatilities. But, as a long-term forecasting model, EWMA is not suitable (try it out).

entry.title: Kalman Filter
entry.content:
This post is about how the Kalman Filter works. Chapter 13 of Time Series Analysis by Hamilton is closed followed although the (Wikipedia page)[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalman_filter] is also pretty good.

Note on Kalman Gain KtK_tKt​:

  • In Hamilton, it is defined as Kt:=FPt∣t−1H(H′Pt∣t−1H+R)−1K_t := FP_{t|t-1}H(H’P_{t|t-1}H+R)^{-1}Kt​:=FPt∣t−1​H(H′Pt∣t−1​H+R)−1.
  • In other literature (including the wikipedia), it is defined as Kt:=Pt∣t−1H(H′Pt∣t−1H+R)−1K_t := P_{t|t-1}H(H’P_{t|t-1}H + R)^{-1}Kt​:=Pt∣t−1​H(H′Pt∣t−1​H+R)−1

In this post, we follow the Hamilton’s notation.

Illustration of 1D

  • parameters: F=0.95F = 0.95F=0.95, A=1A=1A=1, H=1H=1H=1, Q=0.12Q=0.1^2Q=0.12, R=0.22R=0.2^2R=0.22
  • top plot
    • red: actual state variable
    • blue (dashed): predicted state variable
    • blue (solid): updated state variable
  • bottom plot:
    • bars: changes in errors before and after Kalman update |updated - actual| - |predicted - actual|
    • dashed line: average changes.
  • code here

Setup

Notation:

  • p(x)p(x)p(x): pdf of a random vector
  • f(x;μ,Σ)f(x; \mu, \Sigma)f(x;μ,Σ): pdf of multivariate normal distribution

State-Space Representation

The Kalman Filter is used to infer the hidden process X⃗t\vec X_tXt​ (known as state variable) from an observed process Y⃗t\vec Y_tYt​. The setup is the state-space represenation of Y⃗\vec YY:

where FFF, AAA and HHH are matrics, v⃗t\vec v_tvt​ and w⃗t\vec w_twt​ are white noises with

and U⃗t\vec U_tUt​ is exogenous (predetermined at t−1t-1t−1, for example, lagged values of Y⃗\vec YY or variables uncorrelated with X⃗\vec XX.)

We drop  ⃗ \ \vec{}\    to simplify the notation unless absolutely required.

Another View: Hidden Markov Model

Resembling a hidden Markov model (HMM) (see the diagram below), the state-space representation provides the following conditional probabilities

  • p(Xt∣Xt−1)\color{red} p(X_{t}|X_{t-1})p(Xt​∣Xt−1​) from state equation ()
  • p(Yt∣Xt,Ut)\color{green} p(Y_{t}|X_{t}, U_{t})p(Yt​∣Xt​,Ut​) from observation equation ()

Roughly speaking, the task is to find the probability distribution for XtX_tXt​ given exogenous variable usu_sus​ and observation ysy_sys​:

Kalman Filtering

Let Ft\mathcal F_tFt​ be the set of data observed through time ttt

where ysy_sys​ and usu_sus​ are the observations for YsY_sYs​ and UsU_sUs​, respectively.

Recursive Process

The filter produces three sets of random vector time series over time ttt.

step
time
random vector
 mean covariance
forecast XtX_tXt​ (a priori) t−1t-1t−1 Xt∣t−1:=Xt∣Ft−1\color{teal} X_{t \vert t-1} := X_t \vert \mathcal F_{t-1}Xt∣t−1​:=Xt​∣Ft−1​ x^t∣t−1\color{teal} \hat{x}_{t \vert t-1}x^t∣t−1​ Pt∣t−1\color{teal} P_{t \vert t-1}Pt∣t−1​
forecast (predicted) YtY_tYt​ with exogenous variable utu_tut​ t−1t-1t−1 Yt∣t−1:=Yt∣{ut,Ft−1}\color{orange} Y_{t \vert t-1} := Y_t \vert { u_t, \mathcal F_{t-1} }Yt∣t−1​:=Yt​∣{ut​,Ft−1​} y^t∣t−1\color{orange} \hat{y}_{t \vert t-1}y^​t∣t−1​ St∣t−1\color{orange} S_{t \vert t-1}St∣t−1​
update XtX_tXt​ (a posteriori) with new observation yt\color{purple} y_tyt​ ttt Xt∣t:=Xt∣{Ft}=Xt∣{yt,ut,Ft−1}\color{blue} X_{t \vert t} := X_t \vert { \mathcal F_{t} } = X_t \vert { {\color{purple} y_t}, u_t, \mathcal F_{t-1} }Xt∣t​:=Xt​∣{Ft​}=Xt​∣{yt​,ut​,Ft−1​} x^t∣t\color{blue} \hat{x}_{t \vert t}x^t∣t​ Pt∣t\color{blue} P_{t \vert t}Pt∣t​

A few observations:

  • Since UtU_tUt​ is predetermined at t−1t-1t−1, it contains no information about XtX_tXt​, thus
  • As soon as the initial forecast X1∣0X_{1|0}X1∣0​ is specified, the filtering starts to operate recursively.
  • Since the state-space equations are linear and the innovations are white noise, all of these random vectors are Gaussians and thus fully described once their mean vectors and variance matrices are specified.

Algorithm

We (kind of) follows Hamilton’s Time Series Analysis…

The algorithm produces the following sequence

and it is sufficient to describe how to obtain the underlined variables.

X1∣0X_{1|0}X1∣0​: Initialisation

In the absence of any observations, set X1∣0\color{teal} X_{1|0}X1∣0​ to the unconditional distribution of XtX_{t}Xt​ (assuming covariance-stationary):

Yt∣t−1Y_{t|t-1}Yt∣t−1​: Forecasting YtY_tYt​

The exogenous variable utu_tut​ is assumed to predetermined at t−1t-1t−1.

From the observation equation (), marginalise to XtX_tXt​

where () is a Gaussian as a convolution of two Gaussians and the last equation is by definition.

While y^t∣t−1\hat y_{t|t-1}y^​t∣t−1​ and St∣t−1S_{t|t-1}St∣t−1​ can be obtained by performing the convolution, it can be calculated directly using linear projections (see Linear Projection & Conditional Expectation):

  • For y^t∣t−1\color{orange} \hat y_{t|t-1}y^​t∣t−1​:

    where a tower rule is applied to () to get ().
  • To derive St∣t−1\color{orange} S_{t|t-1}St∣t−1​, the residual of YtY_tYt​ is given by

    and thus
Forecasting YtY_tYt​:

Xt∣tX_{t|t}Xt∣t​: Updating the Inference about XtX_tXt​

Taking into account the new observation yt\color{purple} y_tyt​, the inference Xt∣t\color{blue} X_{t|t}Xt∣t​ about XtX_tXt​ is updated from the forecast distribution Xt∣t−1\color{teal} X_{t|t-1}Xt∣t−1​

where the last equation is by definition.

Again, use the linear projection toolkits (Linear Projection & Conditional Expectation) to calculate x^t∣t\hat x_{t|t}x^t∣t​ and Pt∣tP_{t|t}Pt∣t​:

and

where we have used

Updating XtX_tXt​: where the gain matrix KtK_tKt​ is given by

Xt+1∣tX_{t+1|t}Xt+1∣t​: Forecasting Xt+1X_{t+1}Xt+1​

This step is straightforward


and

Forecasting Xt+1X_{t+1}Xt+1​:

Maximum Likelihood Estimation of Parameters

The forecast algorithm for YtY_tYt​ provides the likelihood of observation yty_tyt​

allowing us to set up a log-likelihood function

which is maximised with respect to FFF, QQQ, AAA, HHH and RRR.

Application to Term Structure Models

Following Section 7 of Duffee & Stanton…

Model

The short rate rtr_trt​ is given by

where each factor xitx_{it}xit​ has a mean-reverting dynamics in the risk neutral measure Q\mathcal QQ.


where WitQW^{\mathcal Q} _{it}WitQ​ is a Brownian process under Q\mathcal QQ. This is a generalisation of the G2++ model in Brigo & Mecurio.

Being an affine term-structure model, one can write the price Pt(τ)P_t(\tau)Pt​(τ) of a zero-coupon bond with maturity τ\tauτ:

Here, αi(τ)\alpha_{i}(\tau)αi​(τ) and βi(τ)\beta_{i}(\tau)βi​(τ) are simple functions with parameters only appearing in () whereas Vt(τ)V_t(\tau)Vt​(τ) have a more complex form, mixing parameters across () and correlations among WitW_{it}Wit​. Thus, for simplicity, the Brownian motions are assumed to independent to have Vt(τ)=0\mathcal V_t(\tau) = 0Vt​(τ)=0. With this assumption, the yield rate yt(τ)y_t(\tau)yt​(τ) is defined as

which is linear in xxx.

State-Space Equations

State Equation: For the state equation for the factors xtx_txt​, the first step is to introduce the price of risk to the dynamic model () under Q\mathcal QQ to obtain the model under the real (physical) measure P\mathcal PP. For example, we assume

where λi\lambda_iλi​ is a constant price of risk term. Then, the state equation is given as

where Gi=λiG_i = \lambda_iGi​=λi​ and Fij=δi,j(1−ki)F_{ij} = \delta_{i,j}(1 - k_i)Fij​=δi,j​(1−ki​) and E[vitvjt]=δi,jσi2E[v_{it}v_{jt}] = \delta_{i,j} \sigma_{i}^2E[vit​vjt​]=δi,j​σi2​.

Observation Equation: Defining the observation vector as the term-structure of the yield rates over a set of maturities τ1\tau_{1}τ1​, \cdots, τn\tau_{n}τn​, the observation equation is based on ():

where Aij=φ−αi(τj)τjA_{ij} = \varphi - \frac{\alpha_i(\tau_j)}{\tau_j}Aij​=φ−τj​αi​(τj​)​, Uit=1U_{it}=1Uit​=1 and Hij=−βi(τj)τjH_{ij} = -\frac{\beta_{i}(\tau_j)}{\tau_j}Hij​=−τj​βi​(τj​)​ where i=1,⋯ ,ni=1, \cdots, ni=1,⋯,n and j=1,⋯ ,mj=1, \cdots, mj=1,⋯,m.

Filtering

The application of the Kalman filter goes like this:

  • From time series of yty_{t}yt​, estimate the model parameters.
  • Infer the factors xt∣tx_{t|t}xt∣t​
  • Simulate xtx_{t}xt​ using the state equation for ttt in future.
  • Construct the yield curve at ttt using \ref(E:yield-formula).

entry.title: Linear Projection & Conditional Expectation
entry.content:
Conditional Expectation, Linear Projection, Regression, Normal Distibution and Matrix Decomposition are all connected.

The purpose of this page is to review (mostly to remind myself of) topics related to conditional expectations and linear projections of random variables. Before we begin, a few key notations:

  • ′’′ is used to represent the transpose operator.
  • ⃗ \vec { } \   is used to represent a vector. Unless stated otherwise, we assume a column vector.

Illustration of Conditional Expectation and Linear Projection

The content of this section can be summarised using the illustrated plots below.

special case of normal distribution general case
Y=1+X+ϵY=1+X+\epsilonY=1+X+ϵ Y=1+X+X2+ϵY=1+X+X^2+\epsilonY=1+X+X2+ϵ

codes

  • left: For normal distributions, the conditional expectation and the linear projection with a constant term are the same.
  • right: In general, it is not the case.

On Conditional Expectation

following this…

Probability Density Functions

First, recall the probability density function…

Note: For discrete random variables, it is more appropriate to use term probability mass function…

  • Consider two discrete random variables XXX and YYY.
  • joint pdf (or pmf with m = mass): p(x,y)=P(X=x,Y=y)p(x,y) = P(X=x, Y=y)p(x,y)=P(X=x,Y=y)
  • marginal pdf:
    • pX(x)=P(X=x)=∑yp(x,y)p_X(x) = P(X=x) = \sum_{y} p(x,y)pX​(x)=P(X=x)=∑y​p(x,y)
    • pY(y)=P(Y=y)=∑xp(x,y)p_Y(y) = P(Y=y) = \sum_{x} p(x,y)pY​(y)=P(Y=y)=∑x​p(x,y)
  • conditional pdf:
    pY∣X(y∣x)=P(Y=y∣X=x)=p(x,y)pX(x)p_{Y|X}(y|x) = P(Y=y|X=x) = \displaystyle \frac{p(x,y)}{p_X(x)}pY∣X​(y∣x)=P(Y=y∣X=x)=pX​(x)p(x,y)​

Definition

The conditional expectation of YYY given X=xX=xX=x is defined as
E[Y∣X=x]=∑yypY∣X(y∣x).E[Y|X=x] = \sum_{y} y p_{Y|X}(y|x).E[Y∣X=x]=y∑​ypY∣X​(y∣x).
So, E[Y∣X]E[Y|X]E[Y∣X] is a function of XXX.

Properties

Straightforward to prove the following properties

  • tower rule:
    E[E[Y∣X,Z]∣X]=E[Y∣X]E[E[Y|X,Z]|X] = E[Y|X]E[E[Y∣X,Z]∣X]=E[Y∣X]
  • special cases:
    • expectation of conditional expectation = expectation
      E[E[Y∣X]]=E[Y]E[E[Y|X]] = E[Y]E[E[Y∣X]]=E[Y]
    • conditional expectation of conditional expectation = conditional expectation
      E[E[Y∣X]∣X]=E[Y∣X]E[E[Y|X]|X] = E[Y|X]E[E[Y∣X]∣X]=E[Y∣X]
  • conditioning is to freeze the conditioning variable. so, for a 1D function hhh:
    E[h(X)Y∣X]=h(X)E[Y∣X].E[h(X)Y|X] = h(X)E[Y|X].E[h(X)Y∣X]=h(X)E[Y∣X].

Mean Squared Error and Best Predictor

The conditional expectation E(Y∣X)E(Y|X)E(Y∣X) is the minimizing function of the mean squared error

over 1D functions fff. Thus, the conditional expectation is the best predictor of YYY given XXX.

To prove it is surprisingly easy. Denoting h(X)=E(Y∣X)−f(X)h(X) = E(Y|X) - f(X)h(X)=E(Y∣X)−f(X),
we have

since the last term is zero:

due to the tower rule.

Extension to Random Vector XXX

It is straightforward to extend to the case where XXX is a multivariate random variable or random vector:

On Linear Projection

Following Chapter 4, Time Series Analysis by Hamilton…

Settings:

  • XXX and YYY are as before except XXX is assumed to be a random vector, represented as X⃗\vec XX.
  • Often, one of its entries is a constant 111.

Definition

Given X⃗\vec XX, the prediction function for YYY is restricted to a linear function in XXX:

where α\alphaα is a vector parameter.

The linear projection of YYY on X⃗\vec XX is defined as

such that

For an illustration how the linear projection compares to the conditional expectation, go to the top of this page.

Solution: From the definition, the solution of the linear projection is

Notation: Hamilton uses the hat notation (^\hat{ }^) to differentiate it from the conditional expectation.

  • P^(Y∣X⃗)\hat{P}(Y|\vec X)P^(Y∣X): linear projection of YYY into X⃗\vec XX.
  • E^(Y∣X⃗)\hat{E}(Y|\vec X)E^(Y∣X): linear projection of YYY into X⃗\vec XX with a constant term, i.e.
    E^(Y∣X⃗):=P^(Y∣X⃗,1)\hat{E}(Y|\vec X) := \hat{P}(Y|\vec X, 1)E^(Y∣X):=P^(Y∣X,1)

Properties

  • Mean Squared Error (MSE) and Best Prediction: The linear projection produces the smallest mean squared error among all linear predictions. The proof, resembling that for conditional expectation, is simple.

  • Gaussian and Conditional Expectation: If the random vectors X⃗\vec XX and Y⃗\vec YY are Gaussian, the conditional probability is also a Gaussian with the mean and the covariance equal to the linear projection and MSE.

  • Linear Regression: Consider an ordinary least square regression:

    where ′x⃗i’\vec x_i′xi​ is the iii-th observation.
    The linear projection solution in () paralles the solution

Updating Linear Projection

whose the sub-block at (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) is

Derivation via Triangular Factorisation

To illustrate how one can derive the formula for updating linear projections, consider a simple case where each of YnY_nYn​ is a scalar and apply the triangular factorisation of Ω\OmegaΩ:

Projection with Constant Term

One can show that including a constant term is equivalent to working with the de-meaned variables X=Y−E[Y]X = Y - E[Y]X=Y−E[Y]

Let μ\muμ and Σ\SigmaΣ be the mean and the covariance matrix of YYY (thus, the second-moment matrix of XXX):

Other Transformation toward Uncorrelated Variables

Through the triangular factorisation, A−1Z⃗A^{-1} \vec{Z}A−1Z has a diagonal second moment matrix, i.e. its components are uncorrelation. In this section, we consider two other transformations to map Z⃗\vec{Z}Z into a vector with a diagonal second moment matrix.

Transformations

Cholesky factorisation: From the triangular factorisation, we can easily derive

Then, P−1Z⃗P^{-1} \vec{Z}P−1Z has the identity matrix as its second moment matrix.

Diagonalisation: Since Ω\OmegaΩ is a non-negative-definite symmetric matrix, it is diagonisable

where Λ\LambdaΛ is a diagonal matrix and VVV is orthonormal: VV′=V′V=IV V’ = V’ V = IVV′=V′V=I (thus V−1=V′V^{-1} = V’V−1=V′). Thus, V−1Z⃗V^{-1} \vec{Z}V−1Z has Λ\LambdaΛ as its second moment matrix. (of course, the diagonal of Λ\LambdaΛ is made up with eigenvalues and the columns of VVV are eigenvectors.)

Note: This is nothing but the principal component analysis (PCA)!

Mapping Illustration

Each transformation (which is nothing but a matrix multiplication) can be understood as a mapping of two basis vectors into the standard unit vectors:

The plot below is an illustration of this mapping.

    • triangular: The kkk-th element of the kkk-th basis vector is 1 (as they touch the square). The second basis vector is the second unit vector.
    • Cholesky: The lenghth of each basis vector indicates the dispersion of the data along its direction.
    • diagonalisation: The basis vectors have a unit length and are orthogonal to each other.

Gaussian Random

Following Section 4.6 of Time Series Analysis by Hamilton…

For Gaussian (normal) random variables, the conditional expectation (optimal unrestricted predictor) is given by the linear projection with a constant term. Specifically, let Y⃗k\vec Y_kYk​ be an (nk×1)(n_k \times 1)(nk​×1) vector with mean μ⃗k\vec \mu_kμ​k​ for k=1,2k = 1, 2k=1,2, and let

with

So, the proof is to show E(Y⃗2∣Y⃗1)E(\vec Y_2 | \vec Y_1)E(Y2​∣Y1​) is the same. This is just a matter of performing patient calculations. In particular, once we write down the following pdf functions:

where m⃗\vec mm is equal to () and VVV is equal to (), thus proving the claim. Note that the conditional covariance matrix VVV is not a function of Y1Y_1Y1​ but a constant matrix.

As a reminder, the pdf of a Gaussian randon vector of length nnn has the following form:

Examples: Triangular Factorisation

entry.title: On Parameter Estimation of Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Process
Navier Stokes 2D Simulation
entry.content:
Kelvin Helmholtz 2D Turbulence

This post is about simulating the 2D incompressible Navier Stokes equations in a rectangular domain with the period boundary conditions in both axes. This was a topic I studied in my graduate school days when I used C/C++ and Fortran to implement the core model and Matlab for plotting purposes. The purpose of this post is just for me to remind of those equations and techniques back for no particular reason.

Equations

The 3D incompressible Navier-Stokes equations (wiki) are given by

where u⃗=[u,v,w]\vec{u} = [u,v,w]u=[u,v,w] is the velocity vector field, ppp is the pressure field, and DDt\frac{D}{Dt}DtD​ is the material derivative, defined as
DDt=∂∂t+u⃗⋅∇⃗.\frac{D}{Dt} = \frac{\partial}{\partial t} + \vec{u}\cdot \vec{\nabla}.DtD​=∂t∂​+u⋅∇.

If restricted to the 2D case where w=0w = 0w=0, we can introduce a stream function ψ\psiψ such that

so that the divergence-free condition ∇⋅u⃗=0\nabla\cdot \vec{u} = 0∇⋅u=0 is satisfied. Taking the curl ∇⃗×\vec{\nabla} \times∇× of the first NS equation, the third component becomes

In terms of vorticity ω=−∇2ψ\omega = - \nabla^2 \psiω=−∇2ψ,

Numerical Simulation using Spectral Method

If the periodic boundary condition is assumed, it is straightforward to implement the 2D equation using the standard spectral method with a standard ODE solver such as Runge-Kutta methods.

Fourier Transform

To this end, take the (discrete) Fourier transform F\mathcal FF of ()

where ω^(k⃗)\hat{\omega}(\vec{k})ω^(k) is the Fourier coefficient at the Fourier model k⃗\vec{k}k and JJJ is the nonlinear term (known as Jacobian)
J=∂ψ∂y∂ω∂x−∂ψ∂x∂ω∂y.J = \frac{\partial \psi}{\partial y} \frac{\partial \omega}{\partial x} - \frac{\partial \psi}{\partial x} \frac{\partial \omega}{\partial y}.J=∂y∂ψ​∂x∂ω​−∂x∂ψ​∂y∂ω​.
and F[J]\mathcal F \left[J\right]F[J] is its Fourier transform.

Time integration

While one may apply an ODE solver directly to (), we can first integrate the diffusion term analytically for each time step.

We apply the standrad RK4 method (wiki) to the above system of equations over k⃗\vec{k}k’s. For stabilty of the scheme, the time step δt\delta tδt is set to be small enough so that an appropriate CFL condition is met (see wiki). In particular, we consider the following CFL value based on the Jacobian term in ()

and ensure it to be within the RK4 stability region, or
C<Cmax⁡≈2.8.C < C_{\max} \approx 2.8.C<Cmax​≈2.8.
Note that the diffusion term is not considered in specifying CCC as it is analytically integrated in ().

Discrete Fourier Transform

A python wrapper pyfftw to a very popular FFT liborary FFTW is used to compute any discrete Fourier transformations. See also my own post fftw. For a 1D array, for example, the wrapper provides (i) the forward “physical to Fourier” tranfrom

and (ii) the backward “Fourier to phyiscal” transform

Fourier decomposition

For a function u(x)u(x)u(x) periodic in [0,L][0, L][0,L], its Fourier decomposition is written as

where the kkk-th wave-length is 2πk/L2\pi k /L2πk/L.

Calculation of Jacobian and Dealiasing

To calculate the Fourier transform of the products appearing in the Jacobian term, we use the standard procedure:

  1. apply the `3/2’ rule to pad zeros around the Fourier coefficients of each variables; this is to avoid the aliasing effect (wiki) arising from a product of two variables.
  2. apply the inverse transform to each variable to go back to the phyiscal domain.
  3. point-wise multiplication.
  4. apply the forward transform.
  5. extract the 2/3 (in each axis) of the result to align to the original resolution.

An (bad) alternative would be to apply an convolution, which is a slow N2N^2N2 operation, while the above procedure is about Nln⁡(N)N \ln(N)Nln(N).

Diagnostics

Energy

The kinetic energy EEE is given by

where LxL_xLx​ and LyL_yLy​ are the domain lengths for xxx and yyy, respectively.
It can be expressed in terms of Fourier modes as

where MxM_xMx​ and MyM_yMy​ are the number of sampling points in xxx and yyy, respectively.
In terms of ψ^\hat \psiψ^​, we have

entry.title: Numba is fast and can be faster than Numpy
entry.content:
Source Codes:

  • Jupyter notebook
  • folder

Background

Personally, numpy is the most important package because of its vectorisation implementation. Generally speaking, it makes the code shorter, easier to read, and most importantly faster, in fact, much faster if compared to nativa Python. But, the catch is generally. Certain algorithms or procedures are not natually vectorisable and the resulting vectorised codes can have awkward structures that are difficult to read. They may also introduce uncessary but unavoidable overheads. This problem can be solved using numba, which compiles python codes behind-the-scene into fast machine codes.

Illustration: Using Markov Chain Monte Carlo Simulation

Recently, I had to implement to simulate a Markov chain model, requiring a large number of Monte Carlo scenarios (order of 10M). We started using numpy and it was fast. But, we wanted faster, and realised that the model is a good example where the vectorisation approach adds unnessary overheads that are unavoidable with numpy. So, we considered numba.

Markov Chain


Source: Wikipedia

A (discrete-time) markov chain is a stochastic model with many real life applications. See the relevant Wikipedia page for more information. The model is described in terms of

  • a finite set of states
  • transition probabilities from one state to another state

To simulate a markov chain,

  • set the intial state
  • draw a uniform random number between 0 and 1
  • compare to the cumulative transition probabilities to determine the next state
  • repeat

Implementation

For benchmark purposes, three functions are implemented to simulate the model:

  1. Native Python
  2. Native Python with numby (via njit)
  3. Numpy implementation

Here is a code block. Only the first function is documented. The other two functions have the same arguments and return values.

Observe that the native Python code, which is numba’ed, is as simple as the numpy version. In fact, I argue that it is simpler and easier to understand.

Simulations

First, the number of states should be specified together with the transition probabilities among them. The cumulative probabilities are required as inputs to the simulation

Then, we simulate the model over several steps for a large number of scenarios.

Results

  • When 1M scenarios over 10 steps are used: The numba verison (0.12 seconds) is

    • over 50 time faster than the naive version (6.7 seconds)
    • over 3 time faster than the numpy version (0.43 seconds)

  • When 10M scenarios are used, the numba version (1.39 seconds) is again over 3 times fater than the numpy version (4.98 seconds).

In Closing

In this post, we have provided an illustrative example where numba can be used to speed up Markov chain simulations. Not only the numba’ed native Python code is actually simpler than the numpy version, it is noticeably faster; in our experiments, over 3 times faster.

So, numba is a great supplementary package that can be utilised when procedures/algorithms are not easily vectorisable.

entry.title: On Callble Bond
entry.content:
This content in this note is probably not very standard exposition on callable bond pricing. This is a person note where I try to make sense of jargons such as worst-to-yield, often spoken in practice.

Structure: Callable Bonds

Consider a callable bond with call dates at

If the issuer calls, or redeems, the bond on TmT_mTm​, the redemption amount and the outstanding accrued interest is paid to the bond holder at TmT_mTm​ and the remaining cash flows are cancelled. Here, for convenience, the maturity date is treated as the last call date TMT_MTM​.

Typically (at least in old days), callable bonds are structured so that it is most economical for the issuer to redeem on the first call date. For example, the coupon payments after the first call are based on Libor plus very large spread. In past, when callable bonds were not redeemed on the first call date, such events were surprise news to the market.

  • Deutsche Bank non-call, Dec 2008: [Reuters news](https://in.reuters.com/article/deutsche-bank-bond-call/update-2-deutsche-bank-non-call-casts-shadow-over-lt2-bonds-idINLH25709820081217}{Reuters news)
  • Woori Bank, Feb 2009: Reuters news
  • Monte dei Paschi di Sienna, Feb 2011: Financial Times Alphaville

Pricing Models

Yield-to-Worst Pricing Model

Yield-to-Worst

A widely-used pricing model is to search for the call date which results in the worst yield from the investor’s perspective (or the best yield from the issuer’s perspective), i.e. the smallest yield.

Being precise, let

  • Vˉ\bar{V}Vˉ: the market value of the bond with the unit principal on the calculation date
  • Vm(y)V_m(y)Vm​(y): the present value, in terms of yield-to-maturity yyy, of the underlying-bond associated with call date TmT_mTm​:

    where cjc_jcj​ is the coupon amount paid on tjt_jtj​ and NmN_mNm​ is the redemption amount.

In practice, cjc_jcj​ depends on a floating rate (e.g.\ Libor) after the first call date. But, for discussion purposes, we simply assume it is fixed.

To calculate the yield-to-worst yˉ\bar yyˉ​,

  1. For each m=1,⋯ ,Mm = 1, \cdots, Mm=1,⋯,M, solve the following equation to get the yield-to-maturity yˉm\bar{y}_myˉ​m​ for the mmm-th call date:
  2. yˉ\bar{y}yˉ​ is set to

Equivalently, the yield-to-worst yˉ\bar{y}yˉ​ is the solution for the following equation:

To prove this, we have, by definition,

Taking min⁡\minmin,

Find mˉ\bar{m}mˉ such that yˉ=yˉmˉ\bar{y} = \bar y_{\bar m}yˉ​=yˉ​mˉ​ Then, we have Now, we are ready to formally define the yield-to-worst pricing model

Formal Definition

Definition: The yield-to-worst pricing model is a valuation model where the bond valuation is defined by the following function VVV in terms of a yield yyy:

For a given market value Vˉ\bar{V}Vˉ,

  • yˉ\bar{y}yˉ​: the yield, referred to as yield-to-worst, for the callable bond satisfying V(yˉ)=VˉV(\bar{y}) = \bar{V}V(yˉ​)=Vˉ
  • yˉm\bar{y}_myˉ​m​: the yield for the mmm-th non-callable bond such that Vm(yˉm)=VˉV_m(\bar{y}_m) = \bar{V}Vm​(yˉ​m​)=Vˉ.
  • mˉ\bar{m}mˉ: the index of the call date at which the minimum in () is achieved, assuming that a unique such call date exists. Under this assumption, we have If the assumption is invalid, mˉ\bar{m}mˉ is ill-defined.

If mˉ\bar{m}mˉ is uniquely well-defined, the underlying bond associated with call date TmˉT_{\bar{m}}Tmˉ​ is referred to as the yield-to-worst bond. Because of its simplicity, the YTW bond is often used as the starting point for analysing the actual callable bond.

To demonstrate the concept using graphs, consider a callable bond with the following structure:

  • coupon schedule: three annual coupons with
    {(tj,cj)}j=13={(1,0.05),(2,0.08),(3,0.11)}{(t_j, c_j)}_{j=1}^{3} = {(1,0.05), (2,0.08), (3,0.11) }{(tj​,cj​)}j=13​={(1,0.05),(2,0.08),(3,0.11)}
  • call dates: T1=1T_1 = 1T1​=1, T2=2T_2 = 2T2​=2 and T3=3T_3 = 3T3​=3 with M=3M=3M=3. Recall that TMT_MTM​ is the maturity date.
  • redemption amount: 111

  • [thick grey line]: value profile for the callable bond example described above.
  • [blue/orange/green solid lines]: value profiles for its 1st/2nd/3rd underlying bonds, respectively.
  • [dotted lines]: three market value scenarios at 1.0,conditions 0.95 and 0.9.
  • [dashed lines]: yields-to-worst implied from the valuation model () for the three market value scenarios. The colours match to the worst-to-yield underlying bond.
  • [stars/circles]: yield/market-value pairs implied from the non-callable valuation model () of the underlying bonds for the scenarios. The pairs associated with yields-to-worst are marked with stars and others with circles.

The above figure should the value profiles of the callable bond itself (thick grey line) and its three underlying bonds (coloured lines). Three scenarios of the market value are considered with the following observations

scenario of market value yield-to-worst mˉ\bar{m}mˉ
1.00.048790171
0.95 0.088805872
0.9 0.112737073

P&L Explain using Yield-to-Worst Bond

The purpose of this section is to discuss the validity of the YTW bond as an approximation to the callable bond.

If yyy is sufficiently close to yˉ\bar{y}yˉ​, the minimum in () will be achieved at mˉ\bar{m}mˉ as well. Thus, the callable bond can be valued using the YTW as well:

for ∣y−yˉ∣<ϵ|y - \bar{y}| < \epsilon∣y−yˉ​∣<ϵ for some ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0. Therefore,

  • The YTW bond model Vmˉ(y)V_{\bar{m}}(y)Vmˉ​(y) can be used to calculate any sensitivities of the full model V(y)V(y)V(y) at yˉ\bar{y}yˉ​ and the calculation is {\em exact} without any approximation:
  • Consequently, any Taylor expansion to the callable bond can be calculated {\em exactly} using the YTW bond. For example, the first-order expansion is given by

If, however, yyy is not sufficiently close enough from yˉ\bar{y}yˉ​, i.e.\ ∣y−yˉ∣≫ϵ|y-\bar{y}| \gg \epsilon∣y−yˉ​∣≫ϵ, the minimum in ()
may be achieved in m′≠mˉm’ \ne \bar{m}m′​=mˉ, i.e.

Then, any analysis based on the YTW bond becomes invalid.

To illustrate the above discussions, the figure below shows the error profile e(y)e(y)e(y) when the callable bond is approximated using the yield-to-worst bond:

The three scenarios in the value profile figure are considered.
For each scenario, the error is exactly zero if the yield is near the yield-to-worst, but becomes significantly negative as the yield gets away from it.

      [dashed lines]: Yields-to-worst corresponding to the three scenarios in value profile figure.
        [solid lines]: Error profiles when the yield-to-worst bond valuation model is used.
          Each line corresponds to each of three market scenarios.}

Summarising,

  • The YTW bond model Vmˉ(y)V_{\bar{m}}(y)Vmˉ​(y) is exact to the callable-bond model V(y)V(y)V(y) only for yyy sufficiently close to yˉ\bar{y}yˉ​.
  • In general, the full revaluation must be adopted in order to calculate the change in value of the callable bond,

    Finally, if there are more than one candidates for mˉ\bar{m}mˉ, one cannot define a YTW bond. Thus, any arguments based on a YTW bond are completely invalid

Optionality and Option Value

It is important to notice that, with the Yield-to-Worst pricing model in Eq (),

  • the optionality is captured as the minimum operator is applied across all potential underlying bonds
  • the option value is zero because the exercise decisions are deterministically decided. In order to have non-zero option value, a stochastic model such as described next should be considered.

Stochastic Yield Pricing Model

The model described earlier is deterministic where bond yields in future are completely determined from the today’s yield. This is not a realistic assumption. Thus, an stochastic yield (SY) pricing model should be considered

where YYY is a random variable representing the distribution of possible future yields. Because of the min⁡\minmin operator in V(y)V(y)V(y), we expect to have negative option value:

This is in line with the fact that the investors short the option as the call right is with the issuer.

Whilst it is outside the scope of this document how YYY is modelled, its volatility would be calibrated to market variables such as swaption volatilities. Thus, being precise, the SY model should be written as

where σ\sigmaσ indicates the dependence on, say, swaption volatilities.

The most notable effect of introducing stochastic nature in the yield dynamics is to smooth out the kinks from the deterministic model as illustrated in the figure below. Here, we used the following simple model for Y∼N(y,ν2) Y \sim N(y, \nu^2) Y∼N(y,ν2) with ν=0.03\nu = 0.03ν=0.03.
Notably, the first-order sensitivity becomes continuous (and smooth) as shown in figure ©. Finally, the error profiles are shown in figure (d) when the YTW bond is used to approximate the SY model.

(a) bond value(b) option value
(c) first-order sensitivity(d) error from yield-to-maturity bond
The same callable bond example and three market value scenarios described earlier figure are considered.
  • (a) [black line]: SY yield model P(y)P(y)P(y) as a function of yield. [coloured lines]: The same lines as in here. [squares]: yield/value pairs implied from the SY pricing model for each scenario.
  • (b) Option-value per (): difference between the black line in Figure (a) and the thick grey line in heree.
  • (c) First-order sensitivity profiles from the yield-to-worst model (thick grey line) and the SY yield model (think black line).
  • (d) [solid lines]: Error profiles when the yield-to-worst bond valuation model is used. [dotted lines]: Taken from here for comparison.

Spread-to-Worst Pricing Model

Instead of searching for the worst yield, one can search for the worst spread sss over a given benchmark interest rate curve r(t)r(t)r(t):

where

Stochastic Spread Pricing Model

Similar to the Stochastic Yield Pricing Model, we consider a random variable SSS for future spreads over a given benchmark interest rate curve r(t)r(t)r(t) (Here, only sss is simulated. In addition, r(t)r(t)r(t) could be simulated as well.)

Summary

Avoid YTW Pricing Model:

  • We should avoid using the YTW pricing model because the profile is not smooth with kinds.
  • If the YTW pricing model is the only available option, one should not use the underlying YTW bond because
    • Such a bond may be well-defined to begin with.
    • It can change from one to another as the market changes, making any temporal analysis unstable.
    • For large market changes, the YTW bond becomes a bad approximation to the original callable bond. Instead, one must use the full pricing model ().
      Equally, we should avoid Spread-to-Worst pricing model.

Use a stochastic model (e.g. Stochastic Yield or Spread model) instead:

  • This will smooth out the value profile. Consequently, all sensitivities are well-defined.
  • For large market changes, we have to perform full-revaluations as the value profiles are highly non-linear.

entry.title: Illustration of t-Copula
entry.content:
The purpose of this post (and a notebook) is to illustrate t-copula versus Gaussian copula.

Gaussian and Student-t Marginals/Copulas

Four combinations to consider:

  • Gaussian marginals with Gaussian copula
  • Gaussian marginals with Student-t copula
  • Student-t marginals with Gaussian copula
  • Student-t marginals with Student-t copula

Bivariate distributions with linear correlation ρ=0.5\rho = 0.5ρ=0.5 are used.
For Student-t, the degree of freedom, denoted by ν\nuν, is set to 3.

Gaussian CopulaStudent-t Copula
Gaussian Marginals
Student-t Marginals

Correlation measurement

Here, the following correlation measures are considered:

  • ρp\rho_pρp​: Pearson correlation, also known as linear correlation
  • ρs\rho_sρs​: Spearman correlation, a well-known rank correlation measure
  • ρk\rho_kρk​: Kendall correlation, another well-known rank correlation measure

conversions

For bivariate normal (x,y)(x,y)(x,y), we have

  • ρp=2sin⁡(πρs/6)\rho_p = 2 \sin(\pi \rho_s / 6)ρp​=2sin(πρs​/6)
  • ρp=sin⁡(πρk/2)\rho_p = \sin(\pi\rho_k / 2)ρp​=sin(πρk​/2)
    See, for example, http://www.columbia.edu/~mh2078/QRM/Copulas.pdf

The second equation for Kendall correlation holds for elliptic distributions including Student-t. See https://people.kth.se/~lindskog/papers/KendallsTau.pdf.

Student-t

Note that a multivariate Student-t distribution YYY with ν\nuν degree of freedom can be generated through
Y=XQ/νY = \frac{X}{\sqrt{Q/\nu}}Y=Q/ν​X​
where XXX is a multivariate normal with variance matrix Σ\SigmaΣ and QQQ is a χ2\chi^2χ2 distribution with ν\nuν degree of freedom. The variace matrix for YYY is given by
νν−2Σifν>2\frac{\nu}{\nu-2} \Sigma \quad \textrm{if} \quad \nu > 2ν−2ν​Σifν>2
Otherwise, undefined. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multivariate_t-distribution. Consequently, the correlation matrix for YYY is equal to that of XXX.

Experiments

  • Experiment 1: Consider a bivariate Student-t distribution with the covariance matrix
    [1ρρ1]\left[
    \begin{array}{cc}
    1 & \rho \
    \rho & 1
    \end{array}
    \right]    [1ρ​ρ1​]
    Simulate the samples and calculate the correlations - Pearson, Spearman and Kendall. Observe the bias and variance of each measure.
  • Experiment 2: Simulate a bivariate Student-t distribution, varying ρ\rhoρ. Compare the different correlation measures.
experiment 1experiment 2

Observations

For measuring correlations, the Kendall estimator tends to have smaller variance and becomes unbiased when the conversion to the Pearson formula is applied.
